description: From Middle English maymen, mahaymen, from Anglo-Norman maheimer, mahaigner, of Germanic origin; see mayhem.

verbs.description: maim (third-person singular simple present maims, present participle maiming, simple past and past participle maimed)

entries.meaning: To wound seriously; to cause permanent loss of function of a limb or part of the body.
examples: Three chairs of the steamer type, all maimed, comprised the furniture of this roof-garden, with (by way of local colour) on one of the copings a row of four red clay flower-pots filled with sun-baked dust from which gnarled and rusty stalks thrust themselves up like withered elfin limbs.
